content: edge border work a round of single_crochet around entire mat placing one single_crochet in each st and row and 3 single_crochet in each corner fasten_off 2 condensed instructions continued finishing weave in ends and knot to secure straps make 2 using plarn or sturdier material chain until chain is roughly 60in 150cm long about the width of an adult wing- span if using sturdier material this may be strong enough if so proceed to strap positioning if not place 1 single_crochet in second chain from hook and in each chain to end place 2 more single_crochet in last chain and working in the round add 1 single_crochet in each chain to end add 1 more single_crochet in last chain and join with a slip_stitch more rounds can always be added but this should be plenty secure yarn and fasten_off weave in ends and knot to secure strap positioning straps should be evenly placed roughly 1/3 and 2/3 of the way across half the mat when folded lengthwise through only one layer of the mat when the mat is rolled it will be folded in half so the other side does not require straps strap attachment method 1 loop the straps between the gaps of a row of single_crochet several row below the edge tie the straps in a knot to se- cure taking care not to wrinkle the mat too much strap attachment method 2 position the strap in place above the edge of the mat and single_crochet into the mat crocheting over the straps you may want to go over this several times for added security fasten_off and weave in ends your mat is complete to use your mat lay it flat on the ground lay on one half and pull the other half over your body to move/store the mat fold it in half lengthwise and roll it towards the straps from the bottom pull one half of each strap around the mat tie in double knot tie the ends together to use as carrying strap 3 full-length plarn instructions we generally don t make enough plarn for the whole mat at once instead we add to the mat gradually we generally have a big bag cutting session then loop and crochet until we run out then repeat in this manner working casually making a mat takes several weeks as a side note i like to separate my bags by color during the flattening stage and make balls with one color only this gives me more creativity while crocheting to make the mat more stylish we begin with the humble plastic bag it needs to be flattened so use your hands on a flat surface to make it smooth tuck in the sides and make sure the bag has as few wrinkles as possible we have found that you can stack bags before folding to speed up the process aim for 2-3 bags per stack any more and the stack gets hard to fold and hard to cut
